title: Research Assistant
company: Jain Lab | School of Chemical Sciences, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
description: Developed a physics-informed ML surrogate to predict optical properties (absorption/reflectance spectra) of photonic materials by combining DFT simulation data with experimental measurements, achieving <3% MAE versus high-fidelity benchmarks.

Implemented a two‐stage, multi‐fidelity training pipeline: pre-trained on extensive DFT‐generated datasets for semiconductors (Si, GaAs) and metal oxides (TiO₂, ZnO), then fine‐tuned on limited experimental spectra to correct systematic biases.

Embedded physical constraints—Maxwell’s equations (zero divergence in free space) and energy conservation—into custom TensorFlow loss functions, ensuring all predictions remained electromagnetically consistent under unseen conditions.

Designed and trained a feed-forward neural network (input: material descriptors including composition, lattice constants, defect/dopant levels; output: nonnegative spectral intensities over 200–1000 nm) using GPU-accelerated TensorFlow/Keras with auto-differentiated physics penalties.

Assisted the Jain Lab in setting up and calibrating spectroscopy experiments: aligned laser sources and detectors on the optical bench, tuned pump–probe timing for ultrafast dynamics, and maintained nonlinear optics detectors to guarantee reproducible measurements.

title: Computational Materials Researcher Assistant
company: Center for Advanced Theory and Molecular Simulations
description: Led LAMMPS-based MD and MS simulations to investigate the brittle-to-ductile transition in B2 NiAl, building a detailed atomistic model to track dislocation behavior across temperature ranges.

Constructed simulation cells with periodic boundary conditions, inserted edge dislocations via Burgers‐vector displacement fields, and relaxed cores using the EAM potential optimized for NiAl (accurately reproducing lattice constants, elastic moduli, and defect energies).

Developed Python scripts to automate input generation, data extraction, and post-processing—calculating dislocation mobility, stress–strain responses, and plotting Maxwell‐equation residuals for physical consistency checks.

Analyzed dislocation core structures using differential displacement mapping and visualization tools to identify core splitting and kink-pair formation, correlating these features with observed ductility at elevated temperatures.

Quantified the critical resolved shear stress for dislocation motion at multiple temperatures, demonstrating that thermal activation (kink nucleation and climb) reduces flow stress and marks the brittle-to-ductile transition.

Validated simulation results against experimental benchmarks and theoretical models by comparing transition temperatures, critical stresses, and core geometries; performed finite-size studies to confirm negligible boundary artifacts.
